title: From sand to celluloid (A)
creator_contributor_role: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, production company
viewing_guidelines: Aboriginal and Islander viewers should note this work may contain images of deceased people and caution should be exercised when viewing.

abstract: Black man down (1996, 10 min.)--Fly Peewee, fly! (1995, 10min.)--No way to forget (1996, 12 min.)--Payback (1996, 10 min.-- Round up (1996, 15 min.)--Two bob mermaid (1996, 15 min.)
description: An impressive collection of Australian short films by Indigenous filmmakers which explore the history and contradictions of Aboriginal identity. Richard Frankland's "No Way to Forget" is the story of a young man, working on the Royal Commission on Black Deaths in Custody, who drives home to Melbourne and is haunted by the ghosts of the dead. dead. In Sally Riley's "Fly Peewee Fly!", a young boy teaches his white grandmother and his Koorie father a few lessons on perspective. Rima Tamou's "Round Up" is a tender story about two country boys who discover that their racial differences are not so acute when they are confronted with the multiculturalism and subcultures of the inner-city. In "Two Bob Mermaid" Darlene Johnson presents a beautifully filmed story about a young girl who can pass for white in a racially divided 1957 Australia. Warwick Thornton's "Payback" presents a surreal story of a young convict who has to obey tribal lore as much as he does white law. Bill McCrow's "Black Man Down" explores the need for contemporary Aborigines to be aware of the lessons and spirituality of the past.
